instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
HI , I have a Macbook Pro board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with water damage, no start
water damage around the U500 chip, fan no spin, green light and then orange light
 posted voltages with out battery
<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL>=16.52v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=3.34v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>=3.34v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>=3.38v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>=3.41v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=12.57
IC <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> its geting hot

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> is thunderbolt controller.
If gets hot, some S0 voltages should be present.
So your board turns on, but not booting; make difference between these things.

Fan will not spin until CPU gets very hot; don't use the fan as power on sign for this board!

Post voltage on big coils of the board.
Also check for USB activity.

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
"USB=5.12v"
What this means???
You have a fix with USB power.
I said you to read "How To colleciton" thread, about how to properly check USB activity.

The board stays on and has even CPU core voltage.
Need to confirm USB activity, eventually external video.
Do you get <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> at least?

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>=0v

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Then no USB activity for sure.
I hope you understood how to check it, for the future.

Inspect <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> for corrosion.
Do you get 3V at pin 3?

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 3=0v
no corrosion

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: I notice that when I connect the charger the cpu gets hot and when 1 minute pass start to getting cold and then only voltage on L7130=12.56 and the rest of the big coils =0v

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: sorry, L7560=3.35v and L7130=12.56v and the rest 0v

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: Post <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> voltage, when turned on; pins 5, 6, 7, 8.

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
pin5=3.41v
pin6=0v
pin7=3.41v
pin8=3.41v

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: If L7310/20 voltage is there, then tie together pins 5/6 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and check if <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes on.

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: Now  <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> =3.34v, put everything together and when I started i can hear the chime, but no video, Boot into an OS using HDMI out with internal display but no video,  L8300 =5.17v for 5 seconds and then 0v,  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_EDP_SW</SIGNAL> =3.34v for 5 seconds and then 0v,  <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>=3.38 stable

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: Force external video disconnecting internal LCD.

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: ok, i did it but no video on HDMI external LCD

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Looks like CPU (iGPU) problem.

With internal LCD connected, check if <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD_CONN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> go high; at same time when you get 3V at pins 28-30 of J8300.

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD_CONN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> go high,  pins 28-30 of J8300=5.15V and CPU got very hot , also fan never start working

threads.title: Macbook Pro - Water Damage - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Fan only starts to spin when CPU gets really hot; is the normal behaviour for this board.

If <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> goes high, PCH should enable eDP output.
If signal drops after few seconds, denotes iGPU problem; this explains missing external video too.

I'm very sure you got this information fixed after all.
